0553103547|1.0|With A Game of Thrones, it's the good stuff that sucks you in, but all the problems that leave you frustrated and resentful when its done.<br /><br />The good stuff includes writing that flows well, characterizations that that may be occasionally ripped off but are at least many and varied and usually aren't completely flat (better than most fantasy/sci-fi), an immersive world, tension amongst the characters and factions, and hints of dire developments to come.<br /><br />But please, this is an 800 page book that fails to completely tell even one story. George R R Martin has taken about 8 plots, none of which would amount to even a novella on its own, and put them all in a blender in the hopes that when it all comes out as sludge, you won't notice that it doesn't add up to anything. The constant switching back and forth between plot lines and perspective doesn't allow even a single one to develop in more than a halting manner. I am of the school that believes if you are going to make me read 800 pages and call it a book, and make me wait 3 years for the next one, you better be able to write one complete arc anyway, somthing that has eluded this author. Good grief, when did it become acceptable to write an 800-page book with so little actual content? Huge swaths of this book could be deleted and it would make little difference to the reading experience.<br /><br />As frustrating as this is, it wouldn't in and of itself amount to fatal criticism if the book didn't have other problems. I think the chief one is just that we've seen all these people before. The Catelyn/Eddard/Robb trio seems so similar in feel to the Leto/Jessica/Paul trio in Dune that they could almost be carbon-copies, minus the trappings of setting; Catelyn's lines could be Jessica's in many spots. Sansa is straight out of the pages of War and Peace. I'm sure Arya basically wrote herself. I'm not opposed to borrowing in general, but I prefer that authors make some effort to disguise their efforts in this matter.<br /><br />Strip out all this, though, and you are left with some good stuff. Except in the more vulgar passages, which usually seem simply ostentatious, Martin clearly has a grasp of language. His descent into detail is occasionally tiresome, but often does do a good job at conveying a time and place, and the trade-off is well worth it. While the crush of different characters with hard-to-remember names can make War and Peace look like a one-man play, it does lend the novel a sense of grandeur and scope that is unique and welcome. And the building up of subtle tensions (like the ominous rumblings from beyond Hadrian's, er, The Wall) are well-handled, or would have been if they had ever amounted to anything.<br /><br />Still, at the end of the day, three books came to mind when reading this: a) Tolstoy's War and Peace; b) Stephen R Donaldson's Mirror of her Dreams; and c) Donaldson's Gap series, starting with The Real Story. A Game of Thrones is but a pale shadow of any of these books. Tolstoy has a very similar soap-opera-esque feel, but he is a master crafstmen who had a story to tell, who told it, and finished it. Martin appears to be none of these things, but of course War and Peace is a classic of western literature. Donaldson's Mirror of her Dreams features an incredibly similar medeval-esque setting of political intruige, but Donaldson's story had great imagination, vastly superior characters, and a plot that had an arc and momentun. Donaldon's Gap series had a similar format (character-switching chapters), similarly traumatized characters and a similar willingness to kill off anyone, and similar layers and layers of intruige - but it again had vastly richer and far more believable characters, managed to make even the nasty ones sympathetic at some level, and had a plot which actually moved and allowed the characters to develop in interesting ways and stuff to happen. In short, A Game of Thrones seems amaturish and derivitive by comparison to anyof these books.<br /><br />A book can be of less-than-epic quality and still do OK, but when it comes to A Game of Thrones, I keep coming back to one fact - 800 pages, and it's little more than an introduction to Westros. If I were an author writing an 800-page book, I'd want more to show for it.on to any of these books. <br /> <br />A book can be of less-than-epic quality and still do OK, but when it comes to A Game of Thrones, I keep coming back to one fact - 800 pages, and it's little more than an introduction to Westros. If I were an author writing an 800-page book, I'd want more to show for it.
B00005A46T|5.0|If you haven't heard of Slipknot in the world today, you must be living in hole in the ground. These guys have taken what metal id all about and caressed its underside, turning it into something different. The nine-member band has taken metal and injected it with caffeine and amphetamines. They have shaped what metal is all about these days, and this album is the basis of that. Without truly listening, one might wave off this masterpiece as a raging and blatent wall of sound, but if one looks closer, the wall would become more detailed and harder to comprehend at one glance. As is most apparent in songs such as My Plague and Left Behind, Corey Taylor has used a technique that most avoid, and it works. By singing gracefully instead of very staccato in the chori, he wraps a blanket around the blazing guitar riffs and drum beating, taking away the sharp edges of traditional metal, and turning it into art, something MUCH more. However much they may have toned down, in the long run, they keep the rampage of noise that drew me to them. As is exhibited in People=S*** and The Heretic Anthem especially, it is completely apparent that Slipknot has held, if not gained more of, their completely razor-edge metallic instinct. The one and only downfall of this album is the annoying and somewhat relentless beeps/scratches/whines/sfx in a few tracks. Other than that, if you love metal as I do, buy this album ASAP
B000286S8S|3.0|Wow, this cd is getting some negativity. Some comments: <br /> 1) It looks like some of the reviewers have never seen a greatest hits collection before. Of course it doesn't have EVERY ONE of your favorite songs. No collection would unless (a) you produced it or (b) it came from a one-hit wonder. If there's a song missing, buy it some from itunes or wherever. If Fair Warning is your favorite cd, buy it as well, there's only a one-song overlap. <br /> 2) The live songs: I think part of the purpose of this cd is to support their current (and future?) tours. It makes sense to show people what they sound like now, rather than what they sounded like 20 years ago. Just be glad they didn't replace the album tracks instead of repeating them (now THAT would suck!). <br /> 3) Yep, they messed up &quot;Finish what you started&quot;. Maybe it's a bad joke on the engineer's part? <br /> 4) Whoever listed this song on Amazon must be a fan, since s/he put out a better (if obvious) ordering than actually exists <br /> on the cd's. <br /> 5) Perhaps the saddest thing, this could have been done 8 years ago, if they had done it right the first time.  <br />  <br /> The songs: I much prefer the DLR era over the SH era. Nothing against Hagar, I just didn't like the direction they followed <br /> in the mid 80's. I think the tracklist is ok. There are a few songs by DLR that are missing, but I think it covers both periods fairly well. I'm not enough of a fan to buy the original cds all over again (had a few on cassette in high school), and this collection is a good enough taste of the band for me. Not spectacular, but not too bad. The 3 new songs sound like typical VH with Hagar to me, not horrible but not great either. Putting them right after eruption was Eddie's way of saying, &quot;we're back&quot;, I guess, but it doesn't sound right to my ears. I doubt I'll listen to them much and I very much doubt they'll get much radio play. Similarly, I don't much care for the 3 live tracks at the end, but I can see why they're there. Sammy does a pretty good rendition of &quot;Ain't talking about love&quot;, but I'll take the studio version, thanks. <br />  <br /> The tracklist: Here's where I have a real problem. I just don't care for the later songs, and alternating old and new just doesn't gel to my ears. The sound changed a lot after 1984 (softer, much more synth) so there is a jarring transition every other song which doesn't make for an enjoyable experience. However, ripping the dlr songs and playing them separately does sound good. As a result, the cd's won't spend much time in my player, since I don't want to program them every single time. <br />  <br /> The packaging: The cd digipack is ok. I like the design from Eddie's guitar. There is a tiny booklet stuck in the middle, which is pretty bad. There's a current picture of the band, and that's about it. No old photos, nothing really to look at. A fawning history of the band, which glosses over a lot, but this is par for the course. Nothing much here, folks. The cd's are pretty blandly designed, but as mentioned above, I probably won't be seeing them much. <br />  <br /> And finally, here's my tracklist: <br /> eruption <br /> you_really_got_me <br /> runnin_with_the_devil <br /> aint_talking_bout_love <br /> and_the_cradle_will_rock <br /> unchainedhot_for_teacher <br /> panama <br /> everybody_wants_some <br /> beautiful_girls <br /> jamies_crying <br /> i'll_wait <br /> oh_pretty_woman <br /> dancing_in_the_street <br /> dance_the_night_away <br /> jump <br /> why_cant_this_be_love <br /> black_and_blue <br />  <br />
B0000D96NW|5.0|As any true Machine Head fan knows, since the release of the epic BURN MY EYES, the press and some fans have been less than kind of the bands ever changing sound, going so far as to even cry sell out when they released the misunderstood BURNING RED, one would assume this is due in part to Ross Robinsons name being on the production credits. Obviously these people have never experienced the 'Head live, or they would have seen the folly of their ways after being savagly and brutally assaulted by the pure power of every song live. But, even after a beating like that, theres bound to still be naysayers...well, TTAOE is the bands response to those non belivers. <br /> Originally released overseas in 2003, TTAOE made such a commotion and had metal fans salivating so bad that Roadrunner Records US had no choice but to pick the band back up and release the album stateside,with a bonus track NOT found on any of the expensive UK or Japanese versions. <br /> The album combines all the best elements of their back catalog. The brutally raw metal attack of BURN MY EYES, the groove and 'bounce' of, well, everything they do!, BURNING RED and the maturity that comes with time and experience, and lets not forget the pure, unadulterated rage of a band that broke barriers in the mid 90's and still never got the total respect they rightly deserved! <br /> Stand out tracks would have to be IMPERIUM, a true metal classic in the vein of Davidian, the onslought of BITE THE BULLET with its frantic whispered lines and shouted (growled?) chorus and the epic finality of album closer DESCEND THE SHADES OF NIGHT. It must be heard to be belived! And lets not forget the bonus US track that was actually put into the track listing and not tagged on the end, SEASONS WITHER. Amazing.  <br /> In short? Just pick this f***er up! What with the NWOAHM blistering our ears, Machine Head is truely one of its origionaters and demand your attention! <br /> True fans though, should pick up the 2 disc version sothey can add the bonus demos to their collection. As an extra bonus, it even has the video for IMPERIUM as an enhanced element! <br />

B0000025YL|5.0|This album was an eyeopener when it was released. I honestly thought it was the heaviest album ever and that nothing would ever touch it for heaviness. I was quite literally blown away. <br /> <br />Now, over twenty years on it still gets my motor running into overdrive. It represents a milestone in metal for many reasons. Accept, and this album in particular, were the reason that a whole new generation of metal players emerged. <br /> <br />It was German metal. Now we speak of the classic German metal sound, the classic German metal bands but along with the Scorpions, it was Accept that cracked open the floodgates. <br /> <br />With the release of Restless & Wild they truly hit their stride. The groundwork had already been done years previously. They were amazing live, commanded a very large following for a relatively 'unknown' band and managed to lay down an album sound that was far from demo quality but retained all the raw energy of their live shows while avoiding too much slickness and polish. This album took things up to a whole new level. <br /> <br />Back in the eighties reviewers would describe metal bands as playing 'tight'. Accept were so tight as to be almost clockwork but while still retaining a raw energy that constantly put them on the limit. <br /> <br />'Fast as a Shark' is the one that everybody gets pummelled by and with good reason. It's impossible not to get sucked up by it. It's brutal yet has a lot of melody running through it and it's not agression for the sake of agression. Restless & Wild get's into the slipstream of 'Fast ...' and does well to maintain the momentum. However, it's not until Neon Nights emerges to close side one that the listener finally shakes off the effect of 'Fast ...'. For that reason I tend to play this album on random. Neon is  a masterpiece of mood and oozes power. 'Shake Your Heads' is metal heaven in spite of the corniness of it all. <br /> <br />'Flash Rockin' Man' is one of my all time favourites and the classicPrincess of the Dawn served to let us all know what was to come from Wolf Hoffman in the future. <br /> <br />Udo is most definitely the right man for the vocals. An essential  part of the puzzle. Those that say he isn't singing aren't listening. The man is not your average wailer but he has a lot of texture in his voice and he does control it very well. He is truly unique and Accept just wouldn't have been Accept without him. <br /> <br />For any collector of metal albums this is one of the must have's (along with 'Balls to the Wall' and 'Metal Heart'). At the time 'Restless & Wild' was history in the making and set a trend so many others would pick up on much later on.
0735619670|5.0|Code Complete, first edition, has long been regarded as ?The Bible? for software development. Dare I say, CC2 is even better than the original. It has been thoroughly updated to include OO, internet and web development, as well as new best practices such as test-first development, pair programming, and refactoring.  <br /> <br />Steve McConnell provides a balanced, thoughtful discussion of competing approaches to software development. He also provides a wealth of references to additional materials covering specific topics in more detail. In a field that is often defined by religious arguments, CC2 stays objective on most topics. At the same time, McConnell does not shy away from stating his conclusions on topics that he believes have a clear-cut ?best choice?. <br /> <br />Overall, this book is as much of a ?must have? as the first edition and destined to become just as famous.

0735619670|5.0|It was a pleasure to find out that this book had been updated when I reads news of it. CC2 is a great one-stop 'place' to go to when you want a great excuse to apply Stephen Covey's 'Sharpen The Saw' principle. This updated version has some solid, fantastic, expert instruction on designing from scratch, whether it's OO, writing better routines, psuedocode, nested loops, or at the higher level: agile methods, etc..<br /> McConnell's approach of talking to you, the programmer, is ideal: not too much humor, and an easy to read, but professional approach in the way he donates the contents of his brain: i.e. McConnell's lengthy experience in the field.<br /><br /> I read just a couple of paragraphs in a chapter before work one morning, and the advice I picked up saved so much time that same day. And it wasn't even specific to coding instruction. It was a piece of advice on a philosophy on how he personally determines how much upfront design he should settle on before coding.<br /><br />Reading Software Construction material of this caliber, as compared to some, yet another, new book on a specific language that might look impressive to know, is what makes for a solid programmer.<br /><br /> Refreshing your overall S/W construction knowledge gives you so much more of your life back, because you will have way less bugs and a lot more fun maintaining the high-quality code you are now writing because of CC2.<br /> I mentioned already that he covers OO, but I wanted to emphasize the excellent material he offers in this area. I am now seeing the benefit of measuring the quality of your classes by this guideline: are they true Abstract Data Types. ( rather than just trying to use the syntax that the language provides to its potential).<br /> Great job on a rather thorough re-write of a S/W development staple.
B000002OMN|4.0|Even though Meatloaf has released about ten studio albums, only this one and its predecessor could be described as commerically &quot;very successful.&quot; My theory is that people really LOVE Meatloaf...but only when they're sure he's about to give them what they want. And what they obviously want are the bombastic songs that are helmed under the _Bat Out of Hell_ name. <br />  <br /> _Bat Out of Hell II_ is full of the typical Steinman songwriting--grand and extended song structures, passionate lyrical cliches, double entendrees and crescendos, and walls of vocals. Most know &quot;I Would Do Anything For Love (But I Won't Do That),&quot; and it holds up today as well as it did in '93. Other standout tracks are &quot;Life Is a Lemon,&quot; &quot;Rock and Roll Dreams Come Through,&quot; &quot;It Just Won't Quit,&quot; and &quot;Objects in the Rearview Mirror May Appear Closer than They Are.&quot; Heavier songs like &quot;Wasted Youth&quot; and &quot;Out of the Frying Pan&quot; are good, but the truly moving moments on the album is when Meatloaf is delivering his earnest and passionate vocals--he's truly in fine form on this album. &quot;Objects in the Rearview Mirror,&quot; written by Steinman but semi-autobiographical of Meatloaf's own life, is a beautiful and powerful song. Cynics might laugh at the notion, and sometimes I myself even consider Meatloaf to be a &quot;guilty pleasure,&quot; but you can't deny that this particular hybrid of rock-n-roll (part pop, part progressive rock, part heavy metal) is done extremely well. <br />  <br /> There's been rumors of _Bat Out of Hell III_ out there for quite some time, and if Steinman and Meatloaf are alive and well as this decade closes down, I'm sure we'll see it. In the meantime, pick up this album, sit back, and enjoy the wait.
B00005JLEX|5.0|Just to let you all know, the Seinfeld Season 1,2 and 3 will be sold in Australia before anywhere else! Mid october it is due out, Im so gonna pre-order!
0780020685|5.0|For those of you who feel this is a rip off of the Magnificent Seven, you might want to compare copyright dates! This is the movie the Magnificent Seven was based off of! <br />  <br /> I won't go into the plot of the movie, as you can read that anywhere. I will say that if you could get your head around the Matrix and its &quot;bullet-time&quot; effects, than you can appreciate the cinematography of Samurai. The Japanese are often shown in movies as people who say alot without saying anything, and this is case in many points in the film. B000002MY3|5.0|If there is one CD I really believe everyone should own, this is it. I've had it since the fourth grade, and (unlike a lot of my other music selections from back then) I actually still listen to it. I do know that not everyone will fall in love with Alanis' 'Jagged Little Pill' the way I have, but I really believe that no matter what genre people prefer, everyone has to respect the fact that Morissette is a true talent. This is the album that skyrocketed the singer-songwriter into worldwide fame and fortune. And, although she's yet to outdo her sales for 'Jagged Little Pill' (and probably never will), that success plays a large part in continuing to keep Morissette's follow-up albums on the charts. <br />  <br /> The album starts with 'All I Really Want', it's filled with emotion as Alanis lets us all know (surprise!) what she really wants. The song seems to be directed at a lover who doesn't quite understand why his girlfriend seems to be so crazy (&quot;I'm like Estella/I like to reel it in and then spit it out/I'm frustrated by your apathy&quot;). The second song on 'Jagged Little Pill', and the first single to drop from it, is 'You Oughta Know'. This track is about an ex who's now with another woman. Keeping within the theme of the album, this is another angry, emotionally-charged number putting Alanis at the top of a lot of people's &quot;Wow, is this chick pissed off, or what?&quot; lists. 'Perfect' is the first slow song on the album and it's sung from the point of view of demanding parents. With lyrics like &quot;If you're flawless, then you'll win my love&quot; and &quot;That simply wasn't good enough/To make us proud&quot;, it's hard to tell whether Alanis possibly wrote the song about her own family life, or if it's merely a critique pointing a finger at other critical parents. <br />  <br /> 'Hand In My Pocket' is one of the only songs off of 'Jagged Little Pill' in which Alanis doesn't seem upset at anyone. True, she doesn't sound overly excited about life in it either, but the lyrics are among the more positive and optimistic ones on the album. She basically states that no one has life &quot;all figured out just yet&quot; but in the end, everything will &quot;be quite alright&quot;. The fifth track, 'Right Through You', is among my favourites from this CD. It starts out quite slowly before gradually slipping into another anger-filled song where Alanis croons out her angst-y lyrics in her unique not-quite-but-almost-yelling voice. 'Forgiven' is, oddly enough, actually about going to church. Morissette reminisces about all the times she went to church when she was younger. Reflecting on her choir days, confession, and (of course) famous Catholic guilt. The seventh track, 'You Learn' basically goes through the fact that, no matter what you do, you'll end up learning a lesson at the end of the day. It has very simple music and very simple lyrics to match. It's also the track which contains the album's title (&quot;Swallow it down (what a jagged little pill)/It feels so good (swimming in your stomach)/Wait until the dust settles&quot;). <br />  <br /> 'Head Over Feet' is my very favourite song on 'Jagged Little Pill'. Although it's quite a bit different than the other tracks (definitely not as angry), it fits surprisingly well into the album. It's quite slow, and deals with a lover who (amazingly enough) Alanis doesn't despise. Right after 'Head Over Feet' is another slow song, 'Mary Jane' deals with a girl going through emotional difficulties, and it's actually made me cry a couple times (that's a big feat, considering I have a heart of stone). 'Ironic' is probably one of Alanis' most famous songs ever. It's not slow, but it's not exactly fast either. It's extremely simple, yet I don't think I've ever met anyone who doesn't know at least a portion of the lyrics off by heart. My favourite line? &quot;And life has a funny way of helping you out when/You thing everything's gone wrong and everything blows up in your face&quot;. Moving away from the &quot;slow&quot; songs, 'Not The Doctor' is another great track. It's got great lyrics about not wanting to be the person who's relied on for fixing what someone else has screwed up. <br />  <br /> Nearing the end of the album, 'Wake Up' is an absolutely fabulous song. I am really not exaggerating when I refer to it as flawless. Take the first verse for example,  <br />  <br /> &quot;You like snow but only if it's warm <br /> You like rain but only if it's dry <br /> No sentimental value to the rose that fell on your floor <br /> No fundamental excuse for the granted I'm taken for&quot; <br />  <br /> No matter how many times I hear it, I know it will never grow old. The alternate take of 'You Oughta Know' is no different than the original other than the secret track that's found at the very end of it. Personally, I completely love the hidden track. It was done with no background music at all, and it really allows Alanis' singing talent to shine through. You thought all she could do was scream? Listen to this track, then try to argue that point. It's about visiting her current beau's house (without permission) and finding a letter from another woman there. It really is a great song, I'm very happy that they decided to include it. <br />  <br /> All in all, as previously stated, I definitely recommend Alanis Morissette's 'Jagged Little Pill' to anyone and everyone. It's an absolute masterpiece that no CD collection should be without. It was the second CD I ever bought, and I've never looked back. I know every lyric, every melody, every pitch... it's fantastic. <br />  <br /> THE FINAL VERDICT: 100%
B0001NBMBC|3.0|As others have already said, Subliminal Verses does not live up the the precedent set by Iowa. Iowa pushed the envelope by almost going death metal, while Vol. 3 is more like a heavier Stone Sour. It has grown on me since the initial disappointment wore off, but if you only liked Slipknot because they were almost death metal, you probably aren't going to like this. The one thing that is an improvement is that there are way more guitar leads, possibly owing to Rick Rubin's influence. I can just see him going &quot;C'mon, let's do a solo, Mick. Use that whammy bar. Do it For Kerry King.&quot; Otherwise the production is kind of thin - think God Hates Us All with less bass on the double bass. I don't hate it but it's not great. Some of the catchy stuff is cool but it's overdone. Iowa is still my favorite.

B00003CWL6|5.0|The power of this film is such that when, during my first viewing, someone said something stupid (&quot;Whooo!&quot; or &quot;Sweet!&quot; or something) when Angela opens her shirt, I honestly wanted to smack him. It is also about finding the beauty in the unnatural, the trashy, the stupid, the superficial, and the tragic. Really, the movie is best described by it's multi-level title: American Beauty, the rose which is a recurring image, the vacuous teenaged cheerleader/slut, the suburban landscape, and a piece of trash, floating in the wind. 0156027321|4.0|Who would have thought a whole novel could be written about a boy and a tiger stranded at sea in a lifeboat? Somehow, Martel did just that, and did a good job at it. The ordeal that Pi and Richard Parker (the tiger) go through is vividly described, as they slowly waste away in the hot sun, thirsty and hungry during their seven and a half months at sea. The reader can feel the desperation and depression of their situation. Even though Pi's religious views play a small part in his castaway ordeal, the early part of the novel dealing with his religious awakening seems out of place and awkward in the story. But the other focus of the begining of the novel - describing zoo culture - is pretty interesting, along with Pi's ongoing explanations of animal behavior, particularly that of tigers. All in all, this was a pretty interesting book.
B000286S8S|5.0|Best Of Both Worlds is the superlative collection of Van Halen's greatest hits. The collection combines not only their biggest hit singles like &quot;Jump&quot;, &quot;Why Can't This Be Love&quot; and &quot;When It's Love&quot; but favorite album cuts like &quot;...And The Cradle Will Rock&quot;, &quot;Unchained&quot; and &quot;Beautiful Girls&quot;. Set over two disks, the album far outweighs the band's previous greatest hits collection, 1996's Best Of Volume 1, which was a single disk and let off too many key tracks. The album offers three new tracks, &quot;It's About Time&quot;, &quot;Up For Breakfast&quot; and &quot;Learning To See&quot;, which are merely okay. The one negative about the album is the fact that the compilation was put together to promote the tour which features Sammy Hagar rejoining the band and in the animosity towards David Lee Roth that is clearly harbored by the band. Mr. Roth is featured in no photos and is mentioned only in passing in the linear notes. Also, the live versions of three songs sung originally by Mr. Roth, &quot;Panama&quot;, &quot;Jump&quot; & &quot;Ain't Talkin' &quot;Bout Love&quot; are all from the band's 1993 live album and feature Mr. Hagar on vocals. It's just a little bit petty by the Van Halen brothers and Michael Anthony to not give him any credit. Mr. Roth was a driving force behind the band's rise to superstar status and most people consider the time he was in the group to be their definitive version. That being said, Best Of Both Worlds is a first rate compilation and shows why Van Halen ranks as one of the greatest hard rock bands in history.
B0001ADB8C|5.0|Unlike a lot of reviewers, I understand _Gone Troppo_. It's a sunny album, with a funky post-psychedelic sound, and for god sakes, it's George. Other people find different solo albums to pan ~ but honestly, I can't understand why the guy was so often accused of mediocrity. When I listen to *any* George Harrison album, I hear the genius Beatle that moved freakin' Frank Sinatra with &quot;Something&quot;. My point is that George Harrison is consistently underrated, despite the fact that he's a legendary talent that stands as an admired equal with Dylan, Lennon, McCartney, et al. Some will call that overrating ~ I think they have tin ears.<br /><br /> George Harrison's work demands a mellow, open state of mind: someone that enjoys the complex stylistics of a post-Beatle. Besides FaaB and RL from the Anthologies, we'll never know what a Beatle reunion would have sounded like. Instead, we have the many volumes of Beatle solo work, all of it excellent, to prod our imaginations. To that end, the vastly improved sound quality in the _Dark Horse Years_ collection is a consciousness expanding experience for anyone that wants to go deeper inside the mind that gave us so many memorable songs on the Apple label. Consider it a connoisseur's collection.<br /><br /> As for the question of buying the discs individually or in the box set: obviously, it takes a big fan to shell out a hundred bucks for anything musical. It all comes down to what you value. Personally, I think the DVD, book, and Live SACD are worth the price by themselves. Although it is a more subtly and beautifully assembled box set than the mind-blowing _Lennon Anthology_, it does lack the half-baked rarities and private conversations that are so cherished by hardcore Beatle-students. The Harrison rarities collection is coming soon, apparently, but in the meantime, any fan of the Beatles' *music* (as opposed to their faddish popularity) should give _Dark Horse Years_ a chance. George's was the most exquisitely produced and carefully composed body of work by an ex-Beatle, even though it wasn't as copious and popular as Paul's, or as poignant and direct as John's.y produced and carefully composed body of work by an ex-Beatle, even though it wasn't as copious and popular as Paul's, or as poignant and direct as John's.

Although psychologists and neuroscientists can find nothing physically wrong with him, they suggest Evan keep journals to catalogue his daily doings and perhaps pin down the source of the blackouts. His last blackouts occur at approximately the age of 13, and he is then blackout-free until he reaches college.  <br />  <br /> One night, however, he is cajoled into reading one of his old journals, and perhaps serendipitously, randomly selects a particularly traumatic and gruesome episode from his past. He is transported back in time - to age 13, with a sudden awareness that he can do this at will and alter the past. Of course, Evan tries to right all the wrongs that he let go on in his past, all with the best of intentions, but unfortunately, each seemingly small alteration to the past that Evan, age 13 does, has exponentially multiplying consequences for Evan, age 20. <br />  <br /> Ultimately, this movie is sort of a more violent and darker version of the time-travel themes explored in the &quot;Back to the Future&quot; movies, or the TV series &quot;Sliders.&quot; I believe even an episode of &quot;The Twilight Zone&quot; was similar in concept. 0515123447|4.0|Lee Child writes what is known as muscular prose; short, choppy sentences which are blunt, relatively undescriptive and hit you like repeated rabbit punches as you read. It's a style that works on occasion, and this book is one time that I must confess that I did enjoy it. His main character Reacher is a little too Rambo for my liking---a giant who kills every bad guy with a single punch and never even comes close to getting hurt himself. His secondary characters are a little too cliche', and his plots are less than amazing (I've read 2 of his books and both times the plot has been something that's been done a million times). Still, though, his books make for an enjoyable read-it-and-then-forget-about-it diversion, like eating a whole bag of potato chips while watching reruns on TV. Short on substance but long on action, and Mr. Child always seems to have a good working knowledge of his subject matter. I would have given three stars but some extra-bad bad guys and good suspense scenes bumped this review up to 4.

B0000C6E4D|5.0|The third studio-recorded album, fifth album in the running. Touch, Solace, Fumbling Towards Ecstasy, and Surfacing were the albums that defined Sarah McLachlan as she developed and evolved as the artist we all know and love. Afterglow is another album in the order that should not be denied the same attention give to others.      It is true that this album does not provide the same grit and rock that Fumbling Torwards Ecstasy gave the world... but this isn't called Fumbling Towards Ecstasy, Again now is it? It sure isn't, as was shown by her following album, Surfacing, which proved to be yet another powerful album. Different from Fumbling Towards Ecstasy yes, but better or worse no. Fumbling Towards Ecstasy may have set Sarah into the spotlight of what a true artist is, but a true artist continues to create new music, in a driven state to re-invent and create original sound. Her albums get more and more calmer, if that's the right word. I found Fumbling Towards Ecstasy full of her raw, depressed lyrics from the heart. Surfacing is like she is literally surfacing to the world and seeing the beauty of love. Afterglow seems to be talking about the quiet and calmness of solidarity yet still laced with bitter thoughts. Sarah's albums are each unique in sound, as Afterglow demonstrates itself.       As Sarah does help create her own music and write her own lyrics, her music will inevitably change over the years as her life itself does change as well. From Sarah's own words:       &quot;When anyone asks 'Why did it take so long in between records?'&quot; Sarah explains, unhesitatingly, &quot;The answer is that I was just living my life. I lost a mother and I became a mother. Almost a year after having India, I walked away from music for a few months. I didn't play my piano, I didn't open up my journals, I just really needed to let go of all the pressures and the expectations of 'it's been so long...gotta get this record out' stuff. I felt paralyzed. Taking a break and walking away was the best thing I could have done. I came back to it with fresh ears, listened to the tracks, and I realized that it was all sounding really good and to finish it didn't seem impossible anymore. That's my truth. It's honest, and it brought me to a much happier place. I'm loving music again.&quot; (sarahmclachlan.com)      Another interesting fact about this album is that she did not write a single song on the guitar, it was all written while on the piano.      Her life is in these songs, as can be described by emotions evoked by Fallen, and Stupid. Push is one of her more joyful songs describing the love between her and her husband, Ashwin Sood (percussions).      A much more softer-toned album, but not any less quality than previous albums. Taking you from the sad tones of Fallen, to the familiarity of World on Fire, from the blissful yet chaotic times of Stupid, to times of being that Perfect Girl... this album showcases not only her talent, but her life as well.      I was personally fortunate enough to experience her live on her Afterglow Tour of 2004; her songs came truly alive with the true sounds of her songs. Listening to her album again really livened up the songs.      The glow remains even after listening to Afterglow...
B000002UAX|4.0|The Beatles pretty much became wandering souls after Brian Epstien's death the previous summer. Paul tried to assert his leadership over the others, and they(especially John) resented it very much. George and Ringo were also writing, and wanted more say in the group. The group was starting to break the mold, and each member saw themselves as a separate person. Is it possible that the Marharisi had more of an effect on them than the group would give credit for? I can't say. I do know that the year 1968 was a rather edgy one for the group as John divorced his wife Cynthia as his relationship with Yoko Ono blossomed, Paul was shortly engaged to his girlfriend Jane Asher, but by the end of the year it was off as Paul found his soulmate in Linda Eastman. Ringo had his second child a son named Jason, and George still had Patti. However, the comaderie was dying. The Beatles released a song called &quot;Hey Jude&quot; which would go #1 by the fall, and become the longest to stay at #1 at 9 weeks, but the fact that the single was 7 minutes, and 11 seconds long was showing that the Beatles could do anything. While &quot;Hey Jude&quot; was at #1 they began work on this album, and here's where the fun begins. Ringo would walk out on the group for a week, and Yoko would become more of a visible prescence in the studio, and her avant garde style of music would end up on the album as &quot;Revolution #9&quot; Pretty much a bunch of sound clips put together, but gained notority as the fad of &quot;Paul Is Dead&quot; was starting to climax. According to legend if this was played backwards you would hear the line &quot;Turn Me On Dead Man&quot;. Alot of arguing went on to keep this off the album. The rest shows alot of different directions. There was an animal element throughout it all though. &quot;Blackbird&quot; a folk song take off of &quot;Blue Bird&quot; from Buffalo Springfield I suppose. I mean CSNY did &quot;Blackbird&quot; at a concert at the Fillmore East June of 70. Thenthere was &quot;Everybody's Got Something To Hide Except For Me and My Monkey&quot;. It was about as heavy as the Beatles had got, and I know I would like to record thier version of this song along with Fats Domino's version released a year later on &quot;Fats Is Back&quot;, and see what would happen if recorded while played simultaneously. &quot;Rocky Raccoon&quot; tale of woman doing man wrong, &quot;Martha My Dear&quot; Paul pays homage to his sheep dog. Ringo would use his lone contribution of songwriting with &quot;Don't Pass Me By&quot;, and use it to feul the &quot;Paul Is Dead&quot; rumors. With the line &quot;You were in a car crash&quot;, and photos inside the album of Paul, and what he looked like after the crash feuled it indeed. George brought along a friend also as his buddy Eric Clapton would help out with &quot;While My Guitar Gently Weeps&quot;, and he would take a shot at the &quot;Paul Is Dead&quot; rumor with crying out &quot;Paul Paul&quot; at the end, then there were &quot;Piggies&quot; which was cute little fable song talking about &quot;THE ESTABLISHMENT&quot;. However, George's finest hour was on &quot;Savoy Truffle&quot;. A hard rock song with horns, and believe you me they got down on this, but good. There was also some good old rock and roll too; &quot;Back In The USSR&quot; payed homage to thier idol Chuck Berry, and Berry would return the favor by suing John the next year for plagurism, and &quot;Birthday&quot; which was inspired by watching a 1950's movie &quot;The Girl Can't Help It&quot;. &quot;Happiness Is A Warm Gun&quot; should've been used by the NRA to appeal to the young adults, and thier rights to bear arms, and then there's the hard side where John gets down with &quot;Yer Blues&quot;, and this is absolute punk where it talks about &quot;Suicide&quot;, and then Paul tries to outdo John with &quot;Helter Skelter&quot;, but the interesting part is on this song it's Ringo's first time on guitar. &quot;Revolution #1&quot; is a somewhat unplugged version of &quot;Revolution&quot; the flipside of &quot;Hey Jude&quot;. John also begins to deal with the pain of not having his mom Julia around by writing a song simply called &quot;Julia&quot;, and 2 years later he lets it all out with the song &quot;Mother&quot; on his first album with the group the Plastic Ono Band. I could go on forever with this, but it must end somehow, and I feel it should end with a lullabye, and that's what you get at the end of the album &quot;Goodnight&quot;. Critics said it was irratic, and disorganized; well by this point so was the band as they were going through a metamorphisis of individuality.

B00005JN2F|4.0|I am a huge fan of the original movie Bourne Identity, and of course I had to see this sequel. It delivers lots of action and has all the familiar cat and mouse games, not to mention a few familiar faces from the first film. However, more chases and more complexity to the chases do not a better movie make.<br /><br /> The biggest problem with this film is the shaking camera, which was overdone and became anoying--I had to look away a few times and sometimes it was hard to see who was doing what to whom.<br /><br /> Another problem is that while there were many chases and fights, I did not feel as close to Jason Bourne as I did in the first movie. The story was not as tight this time, and some of the action felt like padding. The resolution of the mystery was not so compelling either.<br /><br /> On the plus side, Joan Allen was solid as Agent Lundy, an excellent addition to the Bourne saga. Allen was believable and compelling in her performance. Matt Damon is still the star, and he continues to shine as Bourne. The film also showcases many believable intrigues and has the feel of real life espionage, which I always appreciate in any film of this genre. It is an intelligent action story, and lives up to the original in that respect.<br /><br /> Compared to other action movies, this is as good (or better) as so many out there. But, since it is hard not to compare it to the first film, the flaws are not hard to find. While good, in other hands it might have been great.

B00000J2SO|4.0|Rainbow was a late 70's, early 80's melodic hard rock band led by virtuoso guitarist, Ritchie Blackmore.  He formed the group in 1975, after quitting Deep Purple who subsequently underwent a rapid demise.      Each Rainbow album featured a constantly evolving line-up of first rate musicians.  By late 1978, the band had virtually dissolved however.  Vocalist and co-writer Ronnie James Dio had left and went on to replace Ozzy at Black Sabbath. Ritchie meanwhile began looking for a new producer, singer and songwriter. He brought in ex-Deep Purple colleague, Roger Glover to help write and produce what became the Down To Earth album.     After some initial sessions with singer Pete Goalby (who went on to join Uriah Heep), Rainbow settled on Graham Bonnet.  He had an unbelievably powerful voice (being rumoured to stand a good 10 feet back from the microphone when recording his vocal tracks!).  With Down To Earth, Rainbow made their most commercial record to date, enjoying international hits with Since You Been Gone and All Night Long.  Unfortunately, Mr Bonnet's non-rock look (short hair and Hawaiian beach shirts) along with his lack of song writing contributions soon led to friction and his eventual departure from the band.      I'm disappointed we didn't get to hear Bonnet on the follow up Difficult to Cure album as was originally intended.  I started to lost interest once hearing his replacement Joe Lynn Turner on vocals.  By this time the group had begun to drift towards a radio-friendly AOR/Foreigner sound which alienated most of their early fans.

And that car chase at the end easily eclipses the one in &quot;The Bourne Identity.&quot; This is a must see smart summer film, just judge it as a stand alone (judge the film and book seperately please). Bring on the third Bourne film soon!

B00003CXDB|4.0|Real-life bigtime investment banker Jeff Beck not only advised Oliver Stone when he made 'Wallstreet' but also stars in this film for a few minutes playing himself at a climactic meeting of topdog-lawyers and bankers. He delivers one of the many exhilarating monologues in this Epic tale of greed, pride and innocence lost. &quot;Now your boss will really start thinking he's Gekko the Great!&quot; He shouts at Bud Fox (Charlie Sheen) who plays a struggling young stockbroker who's desperately trying to get on the fast track to becoming a &quot;player&quot;. <br /> Michael Douglas who plays 'Gordon Gekko' (not 'Gecko' as the Amazon review suggests, the name can be seen in the scene where Charlie Sheen turns on his computer in the morning and finds out it's &quot;Gekko's Birthday&quot;) puts on such a mind-blowing performance he really can be dubbed 'Gekko the Great'. The character is right up there with Don Vito Corleone, Tony Montana, Begbie, Popeye Doyle and some other members of that elite group of high-octane male movie-characters that will long outlive the actors that created them. <br />  <br /> Gordon Gekko is a high profile corporate raider that was probably modelled after Ivan Boesky (the biggest corporate raider of the 80's who eventually went behind bars for insider-trading), Michael Milken (creator and unchallenged 80's king of the high yield or junk-bond) and John Guttfreund (CEO of Salomon Brothers in the 80's who's extravert and bizarre behaviour is documented in the classic books &quot;Liar's Poker&quot; (Michael Lewis) and &quot;Barbarians at the Gate&quot; (John Helyar). <br />  <br /> Michael Douglas seems to have been born to play this part and from the moment he is introduced (&quot;Lunch? whaddaya kiddin' me, lunch is for wimps!&quot;) to the moment we viewers have to part from his hypnotic character (&quot;I gave you Darian, I gave you everything!&quot;) he reduces any leaps of faith that his character may present us with to tiny hops due to his powerhouse presence. In fact, whenever I see Michael Douglas in another movie I have the strange feeling that Gordon Gekko is trapped inside and might burst out at any time to hose us down with sardonic one-liners. (&quot;Love is just an old lie created to keep people from jumping out of windows.&quot;) <br />  <br /> Gekko is truly the mother of all high rollers, and his performance alone more than warrants the purchase of this film. Apart from that it looks great with crisp Miami Vice type of clean-cut shots and scenery. The whole set up is utterly believable. I work in Derivatives Sales in London and deal with brokers, traders and senior decision makers of the world's leading investment firms on a daily basis. Either they all modelled themselves after Gordon Gekko or for some reason Michael Douglas got it exactly right. Aggression, impatience with political correctness and urgency to get deals/trades done is what this movie and real Capital Markets are all about.  <br />  <br /> Charles Sheen plays a believable 'Bud Fox' but one wonders what a late 80's Tom Cruise or Kiefer Sutherland might have done with the part. Charlie never really creates the electricity that Douglas shocks the audience with. A baffling fact is that Stone admits on this DVD in an interview that Cruise called him to say he'd love to play the part but Stone \\"had already promised it to Charlie\\".  <br />  <br /> I won't get into the details of the story here but will post some comments on the general themes in the movie. <br />  <br /> There's the theme that Stone had already explored in 'Platoon' of two fathers fighting for the soul of their son. In Platoon it was Tom Berenger and Willem Defoe battling for custody of Charlie Sheen's spirit. In Wallstreet it's Douglas and Martin Sheen representing the 'exciting but evil' and 'wholesome but tedious' ways to go for Charlie Sheen's character. This theme introduces some good tension in the storytelling.  <br /> The other theme that Stone put into this narrative is the bleeding heart &quot;Capitalism is bad and unfair&quot; jingle. &quot;I don't produce anything...I own...&quot; Gekko confesses at one point. &quot;How many boats to water-ski behind do you need? When is it enough?!&quot; cries a shocked Bud Fox. The moral comments on successful capitalists come across somewhat naive and in my opinion don't really work. I won't go into the details but most people I've met who've seen the movie don't even remember what it was about Gordon Gekko that was so wrong. All they remember is the classic &quot;Greed is Good&quot; speech and ironically most of them agree with Gekko on the issue. The fact that Oliver Stone lets Gekko initiate industrial espionage is the reason I gave the movie only four stars instead of five. <br />  <br /> I personally think this was a real blooper. A man in Gekko's position doesn't need the aggravation of blatantly breaking the law. There's a good plot line concerning a fictive company 'Bluestar Airlines' that Gekko has perfectly legal plans with to make himself rich and get scores of hard working people fired that adds enough suspense to the tale. It seems as though Stone was so set on painting a negative picture of egotistical an a-moral Wall-Streeters that he went one bridge too far.  <br />  <br /> Fact is that, if anything, this movie is like a recruiting video for Investment Banking. What &quot;Top Gun&quot; did for Naval Aviation &quot;Wall Street&quot; has done for Investment Banking. Big corporate banks have never had to complain about the amount of interested well-educated young hopefuls but nowadays there's probably not one person sitting in any dealing room anywhere in the world who has not seen Wall Street. For one I am convinced that if it wasn't for the scenes that have the camera following runners and stressed out yuppies yelling &quot;How about those September fifties!&quot; I wouldn't have been in this racket.  <br />  <br /> The dealing room-scenes are some of the most exhilarating scenes in the history of cinematography. Spielberg immersed audiences with his scenes of Normandy's beaches in '44. Stone creates the same spellbinding grip on the audience without getting anybody shot or brutally maimed. That alone is a great achievement for any director in Hollywood. More so for the man who made a career in gory cinematic violence with the screenplay for 'Scarface' and directing 'Platoon' and 'Natural Born Killers'. <br />  <br /> All Hail Gekko the Great! See this movie again and again. It's full of catchy one-liners that will make you not only the toast of any party but might provide you with more of an energy boost than any Tony Robbins video ever will. &quot;Life all comes down to a few moments, this is one of them...&quot; <br />
B000001GPX|5.0|For those of you who may not know, Carlos Kleiber died July 17th.  He left a very small legacy of recordings, and perhaps the greatest impact any musician has left on his audiences in so few of performances.  I've never heard a Kleiber recording that I haven't had quibbles with about his drastic tempos and furious methods.  But I've also loved every one of them, and very much so this recording of the fifth and seventh.  No other artist, for better or worse, ever could maintain an orchestra at this intensity--live or studio.  Kleiber is furious and fiery and extraordinarily passionate.  His performances are frequently debated but always treasured.  In an era of precise, clean and antiseptic recordings by the likes of Levine, Marriner and Gardiner, one can realize how impressive it is to have a man like Kleiber, who can play more precisely at breakneck speeds than these 'perfect' conductors, and play with such tremendous passion that the performances can live, not as relics, but as vibrant and new creations.  That, perhaps is the single most fantastic thing about Kleiber--you can complain about his tempos and his fury, but you cannot touch his musicianship and his theatrical effectiveness.  Whether you agree with every choice or not, serious music lovers cannot afford to ignore Kleiber (and they never have).  Perhaps Levine could learn an important lesson from Kleiber: Slow down, record and perform less, and make each performance count for something.  Kleiber did.  And he always will.  This is not the definitive performance of the fifth and seventh.  In fact, there are none at all, but Bohm and Karajan both do a good job of giving a strong and more 'traditional' reading, and certainly Toscanini's masterful performances will be able to appease that need.  These recordings are something else.  Just one brief example: everyone knows the fifth is based on a basic rhythmic figure '..._' but what Kleiber discovers is that the first movement, when the tempo is increased andthe larger contours are smoothed, there is a whole larger nature of this work that is almost always lost.  All of the notes are the same in these performances, but you will be left hearing things that had always been there but never expressed.  If the fifth has become a cliche for you (as it has me) this recording will open a whole new life of it for you.  Regardless, these performances, indeed all of Kleiber's performances will open your eyes to a whole new way of considering the music.  You cannot afford to ignore Kleiber.  We love you, Maestro Carlos Kleiber, and we thank you for everything you've given us.
B0002858YS|4.0|The Killers will not change your life. <br /> <br />That said, they are a quite talented band who have released an entertaining and thoroughly enjoyable album. <br /> <br />\\"Hot Fuss\\" is catchy, clever, sing-along-able, and undoubtedly being labeled right now as the \\"Next Big Thing.\\"  And if the Next Big Thing is a band with cute songs played by cute musicians, that label may be accurate.  The formula seems to work consistently, and I'll say this for them:  I'd be much happier to see them become the Rock Stars to Watch for the next two months than Maroon5 (I'd like to flog whatever idiot decided that they belonged to the rock genre) or Nickelback. <br /> <br />The Killers' live shows will probably be fraught with fifteen-year-old girls who \\"love, love, love\\" Avril Lavigne, Coldplay, and the Dave Matthews Band (and therefore have no semblance of real musical taste or discrimination and listen mainly to whatever comes onto their radio station), so I will probably never attend one. <br /> <br />But I'm happy to let \\"Hot Fuss\\" be a guilty pleasure, a little like the musical equivalent of cotton candy.  It's fluffy, light, airy, sweet, a bit sickening in large quantities, and ultimately unmemorable, but when you're in the mood, it might be just what you're craving.
0345357116|5.0|Next to The Silmarillion, Unfinished Tales is probably your best resource for learning more about the history and behind-the-scenes events that took place during, and before the War of the Ring. <br /> <br />The book begins with a summery and overview by editor Christopher Tolkien, who as you may have figured out, is John Ronald Reuel Tolkien's son. There's also an introduction, explaining why Christopher Tolkien left some texts unaltered, or why he altered, or did not give altered versions, or definitions and clarifications between differing versions of similar stories...it's all a little long-winded and not entirely necessary in my humble opinion. But perhaps it is important to some. Unfinished Tales is, after all, a large compilation of the scraps and tidbits of information that Professor Tolkien scrawled out in spare time, put together and alongside entire revisions of different stories. I can't imagine the sticky process it took to put this all together. <br /> <br />The book is divided into four sections. <br /> <br />The First Age section entails the story of Tuor, the escaped slave of Morgoth, warned by the \\"god\\" of waters, Ulmo, of the impending danger to the bulwark fortress of Gondolin. Tuor journeys with the aid and guidance of a sea-faring Elf, Voronw, to the stronghold of Gondolin, and offers his message at last to its great king. Since the tale ends here (with only cursory description of the events that followed), I recommend reading The Silmarillion first, if you haven't already, to find out how it turns out. I have, but some of the details were difficult to recall. <br /> <br />Following is the incredibly tragic (and in this rendition, long!) tale of Turin, or rather, Narn I Hn Hrin, the tale of the children of Hrin. I read it because I didn't want to leave anything skipped, but it's only a more detailed retelling of the same story found again in The Silmarillion. It's such a sad, sordid tale that I don't think I would have lost anything by skipping over it. <br /> <br />The Second Age section tells the story of Aldarion, a future king of Nmenr, whose love for the sea is threatened by his love for the maid Erendis, vice-versa. I thought the story was woven incredibly well, except for the fact that it ends abruptly. (I was upset, until I closed the book and remembered that -- duh -- they're UNFINISHED Tales!) From all indications, the ending wasn't too happy anyway. But the story is still of high value for its descriptions of the island of Nmenr. <br /> <br />There is a brief recounting of genealogies of the line of Elros, the first king of Nmenr, and then a scattered gathering of information about Galadriel and her relationship to Celeborn. Various different versions are compared, very little is concretely presented.  <br /> <br />The Third Age is probably my favorite section. It would appear that interest, at least in my case, grows stronger as the time draws closer to the War of the Ring. The first story, The Disaster of the Gladden Fields, is virtually all-new material regarding the march of Isildur after he cut the One Ring from Sauron's hand, how Isildur's army was overtaken by orcs, and how Isildur found his end. There's even a little information about what King Elessar (Aragorn, of course) found in the tower of Orthanc following Saruman's demise!  <br /> <br />Then there is the tale of the great grandsire of the Rohirrim, Eorl, and his assistance that he provided to Cirion, the steward of Gondor, in his greatest need, much as Thoden later did. Unfortunately, this tale tells of how Eorl led his troops forth, and all kinds of details about his journey -- and cuts short just as the battle begins. Don't blame Christopher Tolkien though...it's one of the Unfinished elements. We're also told of the pledge between Gondor and Rohan, and of the gift of the land of Rohan to the Eorlingas. <br /> <br />Then we get some more, extra information about the Quest of  Erebor, where Bilbo Baggins of the Shirewas first persuaded to join thirteen dwarves on an impossible mission to reclaim the great dwarf treasure hoard which was stolen by the dragon Smaug. It is told from Gandalf's perspective to the hobbits inside Minas Tirith following the coronation of Aragorn, which gives it an added bonus, much like seeing extended material on the special extended DVD of the movie. <br /> <br />There are also stories that fill in what happened during the Hunt for the Ring, including a confrontation between the Nazgl and Grima Wormtongue, and the other goings about that the Dark Riders conducted. <br /> <br />The Battle for the Fords of Isen is background, merging with the story in The Two Towers just as Thoden and his troops arrive at Helm's Deep. It also deals with Thodred's death, and the valor that he, Elfhelm, Grimbold, Erkenbrand, and omer and other generals showed during the decline of Rohan's kingdom. <br /> <br />Part four deals quickly with three things: The Dredain (the forest-dwellers briefly seen in Return of the King book, and also the originators of the Pkal-men), the Istari, and the Palantiri. All three fill a mere forty pages, but still provide many interesting and awesome facts about the Seeing-stones, Gandalf's arrival upon the shores of Middle-Earth, etc. <br /> <br />There's also a large index of names and places in the back. <br /> <br />This book is fundamental for hard-core, book-reading fans of Tolkien. You can learn all sorts of behind-the-scenes events that took place in Middle-Earth, and then shock (or repulse) your friends, or just fill out your knowledge of Tolkienology with peripheral information. It's not quite as enjoyable to read as the linear, completed works like the trilogy, the Hobbit, or even the Silmarillion provide, but still very useful. Most likely the fact that you're looking this book up means you should buy it, and I recommend you do.

B00004TH7Z|5.0|I, like many other Maiden fans, was extremely pleased to here that Bruce Dickinson and Adrian Smith were rejoining this metal monster. I was less then pleased that Janick Gers was staying on, but I guess you can't win them all. (It's just that damn dancing around the stage.)<br /><br /> I really enjoyed the Blaze Bayley albums. I thought &quot;Sign Of The Cross&quot; and &quot;The Clansman&quot; were wonderful. (But, with Steve Harris writing both, what do you expect?) Yet, something was missing...<br /><br /> No more! The energy is back. Dickinson and Smith have revitalized this band like never before. The songs on this are amazing. I would go as far as to call this the first &quot;essential&quot; Iron Maiden album with Bruce since &quot;Seventh Son Of A Seventh Son.&quot; I truly feel that the really good songs on &quot;No Prayer For The Dying&quot; and &quot;Fear Of The Dark&quot; could have been combined into one album. (What in the hell is &quot;Weekend Warriors&quot; doing on a Maiden album, anyway?) Kevin Shirley's production gives this album a very &quot;live&quot; feel, and keeps the band from sounding over-produced and computerized.<br /><br /> The new three-guitar set-up doesn't make a noteworthy difference in the sound; it just adds an extra lead guitar style. Dave Murray's and Jan Gers's respectable lead styles are as distinguishable as before, but hearing Adrian's tone come through makes me sleep a little better at night. I always thought his tone, combined with Davey's, made the band's sound. Jan's lead style was a little to &quot;hard rock,&quot; and not &quot;metal&quot; enough, on past albums, and I would be remiss to not mention it here. It is, on this, however, subdued to the point that it doesn't stop me from listening... loudly. And those solos... those solos... BRING THEM ON!! Hearing Davey and Adrian go at it again restores my faith in music.<br /><br /> Bruce is still as great as ever. His voice seems to get better with age. His energy comes through loud and clear. And that bass guitar... Steve Harris... STEVE HARRIS!! The man is a true original on the instrument, and this recording is no exeption. His rapid-finger midrage bass tone drives these songs... along with Nicko McBrain's drumming. That lunatic is as fluid on the &quot;tops&quot; (as he calls them) as on any other album.<br /><br /> And these songs... Smith and Dickinson were always good songwriters, and having their input seems to make this album really shine, combined with Gers, Murray, and, of course, Harris (the band's founder, main songwritter, and the disc's co-producer). Harris's trademark is all over this. I don't think he's ever put a bad song on a Maiden album. His writing credit is on all ten tracks, but &quot;Blood Brothers&quot; is, oddly, the only one he has sole credit on. (He usually has three or four.) Even Davey Murray (the only other original member, with Harris) has two credits on this disc. McBrain is the only member of the band without songwriting credit, but he never has had one.<br /><br /> The album kicks off with &quot;The Wickerman,&quot; one of the best songs the band has ever recorded (written by Smith, Harris, and Dickinson). That chorus, &quot;YOUR TIME WILL COME!,&quot; is sure to become a Maiden concert chant... not to mention Smith's solo; one of his best ever. Other stellar songs include &quot;Nomad,&quot; &quot;Ghost Of The Navigator,&quot; &quot;Blood Brothers&quot; (written by Harris after the death of his father), and &quot;Out Of The Silent Planet.&quot; Come to think of it, I don't think there is a bad song on this whole disc.<br /><br /> These guys are almost in there fifties. (Nicko actually is.) And, they can play it louder and longer then guys half their age, and play it with more energy. Anyone who thinks that &quot;metal&quot; is a depressed twenty-something with an out of tune seven-string needs to buy this and listen to it intently... maybe even take notes.<br /><br /> I am truly impressed... UPTHE IRONS!!am truly impressed... UP THE IRONS!!

This was the first Dream Theater album I ever listened to, and I've been a fan ever since. It has 2 discs, let me give you the run-down of them. <br /> Disc 1: You may listen to it and not like it too terribly much, but after several listens it begins to grow on you. The first track &quot;The Glass Prison&quot; is my favorite song of all time. Lasting 13:43, it's also the longest song ever produced by Dream Theater ( I think...). It is very, very Hard Rock, and is filled with sweet-sounding solos, great vocals, killer drum beats, and a bass that flies from its introduction. It rocks plain and simple.  <br /> The other Tracks on the album are also very good, they will grow on you, and you will also appreciate them in time. but I'll spare you the trouble about reading about every one of them. <br /> Disc 2: A rip-off of Scenes From A Memory (which you should buy), the 8-song disc is an entire story, only not as dark, and weird as SFAM. It has much happier sounds, but it extremely great. Dream Theater has found a sound they can call their own, one story on one CD, and it works for them, they need to continue doing this. All the songs on this disc are good, from the Overture as an introduction, to the powerful, emotional Grand Finale.  <br /> These guys are musical geniuses, and nobody tops them, it's only a shame they are not as recognized as many of these terrible, no-talent rock bands we find today. <br /> This album is a great addition to your CD collection, that's why I give it 5 stars, and it definitely deserves it.
B000286S8S|4.0|Greatest hits albums target two groups of people: <br /> 1. Diehard fans who will buy it: a) To keep their collection complete, b)to pick up the obligatory new songs, and c) to get remastered, cleaner sounding versions of the classics. <br /> 2. Casual fans who just want the songs they've heard on the radio. <br />  <br /> For the first camp, of which I am a member, the Roth era albums have already been remastered and released, so it's the Hagar era songs that benefit from the remastering. As with Best Of Volume 1, someone screwed up the mix of one of the classics - remember the verse swap on Runnin' With The Devil on BOV1? Well, as other reviews have noted, on BOBW, they forgot to fade out Finish What Ya Started, so the end of the song continues at normal volume until it just abruptly stops. Apparently, VH is required to have at least one screw up on every compilation album. Then there's the three new Sammy songs. None of these are gonna be remembered as classics. It's About Time has grown on me a bit, and is probably the best of the three. Learning To See sounds like a Hagar solo song - not bad, not great. Up For Breakfast is the weakest of the new tunes. <br />  <br /> For the casual fans, this really is a pretty comprehesive collection of singles the band has released from &quot;Both Worlds&quot; -DLR & SH. The only glaring omissions I see is the under-representation of Fair Warning, which could have been remedied by replacing the unnecessary live tracks with Mean Street and So This Is Love. They could also have included Don't Tell Me, as this was the first single from Balance (and the best song on the album.)  <br />  <br /> Other than that, I see people whining about their personal favorites not being there, or the play order of the songs. If you're a die hard, you've already got the whole catalog anyway, so why does it matter so much if some of your personal favorite album tracks aren't on there? Also, I kind of like the Dave-Sam-Dave-Sam ordering of the songs. I always felt the chronological ordering of BOV1 was kind of boring - I like to mix the tunes up. <br />  <br /> As for ignoring the Gary Cherone album - why is this a surprise to anyone? The album was a failure, there are no hits on it, and Sammy is back in the band. If you want to hear VH3 songs so badly, go to the cutout bin and pick up VH3 for $1.99! <br />  <br /> In summary, this collection, while imperfect, as most best of's are, is must have for die hard fans, and serves as a great start for casual fans. <br />

B0002234LS|3.0|Secret Window(2003)<br /><br /> If you happen to be one of Stephen King's &quot;Constant Readers&quot;, good adaptations of his novels/short stories come around once in a blue moon. Fans fondly remember movies such as &quot;The Shining&quot;, &quot;Misery&quot;, &quot;Cujo&quot;, &quot;Christine&quot;, &quot;The Green Mile&quot; and &quot;The Shawshank Redemption&quot;, but after that things got more than a little mediocre, with &quot;Pet Semetary&quot; and &quot;The Dark Half&quot; being the only movies watchable. &quot;Secret Window&quot; was brought to the big screen by writer/director David Koepp, and he based his movie on Stephen King's Novella 'Secret Window, Secret Garden', which can be found in the book 'Four Past Midnight'. After Koepp drafted the Screenplay for &quot;Secret Window&quot;, he hired uber-popular actor Johnny Depp as the main character(Mort Rainey), and Timothy Dalton, who starred in 'The Dark Half' movie. So in the world of King-dom, does &quot;Secret Window&quot; stand as a triumphant adaptation, or a miserable failure? Read on to find out...<br /><br /> Plot-<br /><br /> Mort Rainey is an accomplished novelist working on a brand new novel when an unexpected knock at the door changes his life forever. A man named Jack Shooter(Played by John Turturro) claims that Rainey stole the story he wrote 7 years ago. Rainey is disbelieveing at first, but after reading Shooter's manuscript, he realizes his story and Shooter's are exactly the same, and he can't believe that Shooter is accusing HIM! As Shooter grows more impatient with Rainey's inability to admit that &quot;he stole his story&quot;, Shooter begins wreaking havoc on Rainey's life, first killing his dog, to burning down his ex-wife's house, and finally resorts to murdering to get Rainey's attention. Mort Rainey is soon thrust into his own story, and only the ending can solve his mystery......<br /><br /> Acting/Directing/Etc.-<br /><br /> &quot;Secret Window&quot; definitely benifits from the cast, as Johnny Depp('The Pirates of the Carribean', 'Edward Scissorhands') and John Turturro('The Green Mile', 'O Brother Where Art Thou?') are both magnificent actors, and fortuneatly the have the most important roles in the film. Johnny Depp, much like his role in 'The Pirates of the Carribean' as Captain Jack Sparrow, seems distracted, sleepy, lazy, and disillusioned, and Depp does a magnificent job playing the washed-up writer. Turturro plays Jack Shooter, the angry writer from Mississippi with an unmistakeable southern drawl, and Turturro does a good job playing the &quot;country hick&quot;, and his accent is believable at the same time. David Koepp does a decent job directing, while I had no problems with it, there wasn't anything that distinguishes &quot;Secret Window&quot; from any other movie in terms of directing. What really hurts 'Secret Window' is how the screenplay seems to drag along, and what little action there is turns out to be a tad mellow and disappointing, and the big &quot;showdown&quot; you might be expecting never happens. For that, &quot;Secret Window&quot;, while being a Horror movie, isn't scary AT ALL, and turns out being much more of a drama with a disturbing ending if you ask me. Unlike critics of &quot;Secret Window&quot; I don't think you will figure out the plot twist unless you have read the books, as it isn't easy to decipher otherwise.<br /><br /> Opinion-<br /><br /> Overall, &quot;Secret Window&quot; is a good adaptation of the novel, but I feel that the plot just simply drags on in many places, and when the viewer finally gets to the climax, it's nothing special. If you plan on buying &quot;Secret Window&quot; because you want a &quot;scary&quot; movie, I feel you may be more than a little disappointed. In the end, &quot;Secret Window&quot; is worth a rent, but not worth spending more than $10.00's of your hard earned cash.<br /><br /> RECOMMENDED FOR FANS OF STEPHEN KING, STEPHEN KING MOVIES, AND JOHNNY DEPP. DON'T COME IN EXPECTING A HORROR MOVIE, MORE OF A DRAMA! WORTH A RENT, BUT I DON'T RECOMMEND BUYING IT!<br /><br /> Also Recommended-<br /><br /> The Shining- Stephen King(DVD)<br /><br /> Misery- Stephen King(DVD)<br /><br /> Four Past Midnight- Stephen King(Novella Collection)<br /><br /> Thanks For Reading!IN EXPECTING A HORROR MOVIE, MORE OF A DRAMA! This cd is extremely atmospheric, especially the now well known song &quot;Freezing Moon&quot;. It is a very dark work of old school black metal.   The few negatives I can think of for this album is slight repetativness, though for most its not an annoyance. The vocals of course are a huge debate, as Mayhem's vocalist dead died by his own hand before this album was recorded and so another voice was brought in. At times the vocals are very dark and evil, such as on freezing moon, while at others pitiful and almost humerous.   I recommend this album for any fan of black metal who wants to delve into the genre's past.
B0000C7PQK|5.0|My nascent advent into the world of ambient/new age/world music has been a very pleasurable and mind opening experience. I tried Deep forest as well as Enigma, Deep forest being more down to earth, giving more of an earthy feel as it takes you to the heart of different continents, whereas Enigma is more outworldly, a quality much more prevalent in the CD's that came after &quot;cross of changes&quot;. After repeatedly listening to the &quot;greatest hits collection&quot;, it feels like enigma's first chapter is not the First 4 cds, but this new electronic feel to the music more prevalent in &quot;Voyageur&quot; started converging towards it much sooner after &quot;cross of changes&quot;. So the first chapter ended with the first 2 CD's. I believe enigma evolved into the so called new enigma much sooner than voyageur. <br />  <br /> My picks on this CD... <br />  <br /> From East to west (Track 1, 5 stars)... The familiar Enigma intro signature tune with a nice aquatic soundscape. You feel like you are under water with the whales and dolphins in deep ocean but the ocean is gentle not stormy. <br />  <br /> Voyageur: (Track 2, 4 stars) will grow on you. With Cretu' Digitally Synthesized jabbering, it's like being in a maze or a fog. Cool. The bass hammering is beautifully interspersed with the female (I believe sandra) whisphering. Nice layering of sounds with an aquatic treble damped quality, with bass on higher side than the treble. Kind of a like dolby sound. Again gives you an underwater feeling. <br />  <br /> Page of cups: (Track 4, 5 stars) This is etheral stuff, with a beautiful gentle electronic sound coupled with funky groove and an aquatic dolby damped feel.  <br />  <br /> &quot;Boum-Boum&quot;: (Track 5, 3 stars): poppish but I still like the feel of the music. Interspersed are the electronic techno samples. And sandra voice feels nice and refreshing. <br />  <br /> In the shadow, In the light: (Track 8, 5 stars)...fanstastic stuff...If cretu's Digitallyaltered voice fits the music, this is the one. <br />  <br /> Piano: (Track 10, 5 stars)...This a short beautiful peace...to be heard with the lights out and the curtains down, and let yourself slip away. Meditatively serene stuff. <br />  <br /> Following the sun (Track 11, 4 stars)...Maybe Cretu could have chipped down on the &quot;yay yay yay&quot; shouting...but still not a bad one to close the compilation and offcourse we have our sandra cretu here ..familiar terrain. <br />  <br />  <br />  <br /> Downers:  <br />  <br /> &quot;Incognito&quot;...not that good..feels more like techno rock, not what I am looking for in an enigma CD. <br />  <br /> &quot;Weightless&quot;...this is nothing but a filler just to inflate cd playing time. Enigma should stop  <br /> putting stuff like this just to inflate their running time. We'll buy an enigma CD even if it is 44 mins instead of 47 mins.  <br />  <br /> &quot;look of today&quot;...has the &quot;TNT for the brain&quot; feel to it but still felt it was too poppish with cretu's voice...not what I want in enigma. <br />  <br /> 'Total eclipse of the moon&quot;..This was not required...just for inflating run time. <br />  <br /> 7 good singles, 2 not that good singles and 2 fillers (total eclipse, weightless)...so overall Thumbs Up!!! <br />  <br /> The great thing is that this is electronic new age but the kind you can fall of to sleep listening to. Because the music is made so errie sounding, even with the jazzy electronic content in places, it still has this foggy/haze-like acoustic quality. The treble is muted and the bass is kept a bit more, giving you that cozy acoustic feel. When I listen to this CD, I feel like I am in a private glass cocoon with carpeted floors, I can see the see the outside world through the glass but cant hear anything from the outside world except the throbbing vibrations of outside activity. A Beautiful cozy feeling. <br />  <br /> I dont think Cretu's singing messes the CD...it's just that fans are so used to the regular female voice for over a decade that it will take some time to get adjusted. But I am sure Cretu will get accepted since enigma's music is not about much singing anyway. Its about creating an atmosphere.  <br />  <br /> Enigma doesnt need the monks any more...Their musical language has evolved. The king is (not) dead, long live the king !!!
