B000000W5L|5.0|This is it.  There is no discussion.  This is the greatest rock 'n' roll album ever recorded.  Seething, dark, enraged, dirty, and ultimately redemptive--Exile on Main Street is an album that grows better each and every time you listen to it.  From the wild, raucous, unholy barnburner that is Rip this Joint to the heartfelt sorrow and hope of Shine a Light, from the mournful Torn and Frayed to the explosively driving All Down the Line, this is an album that has everything and does not waste a single track. <br /> <br />The songwriting and the performances are both pulled from the depths of the Stones' souls on this one--they quite simply never sounded better, not even on their legendary '60s records.  The rockers rock harder and the blues...that sweet, sweet gospel-and-country-infused blues that no one else ever did quite the same...it's at its absolute peak here. <br /> <br />But it's more than just a compilation of great tracks.  The songs of Exile are definitely OF Exile--both sonically and thematically they hang together and stand apart from the Stones' other work. <br /> <br />But it's more than just a compilation of great tracks that sound similar.  While this is no concept album, it still tells a story on a hidden, basic level--a story of alienation amid a world of self-destructive carousing, of raggedness and exhaustion and depression and pain and love leading to a hope of redemption.  It will hit you as you listen to the world-weary Shine a Light--you will realize you have just taken a journey which is coming to an end, and then you will celebrate with Soul Survivor. <br /> <br />Apologies and respects and all that, but I can't believe that the Beatles could ever have come up with an album like this if you gave them a million years.

B000002P2W|5.0|Peter's poor midlife crisis set to music.  If only we all had his problems back in '75, right?  This Who album, although easily not my favorite, has a strange pull to it so as it keeps ending up in my cd player.  It's very easy to see just how this album seperates itself from the rock opreas Tommy and Quadrophenia, but I see this album as a second cousin to Who's Next, albeit, a toned down, somber second cousin.  Ok, fine, the surley, obnoxious, drunkard of a second cousin.   <br />  The Who here have returned to their bare-bones, stripped down version of rock that was temporarily abandoned for Quadrophenia, their previous release.  The sound is fresh and pleasing as they may have been sensing the age of synthetic overproduction that was soon to come later in the decade.  This album is filled with songs of hopeless despair, although the tone suggests an -oh f**k it- attitude rather than a bland -so what- outlook.  It is easily the Who's most underated, or overlooked material outside of the popular offering Squeeze Box, which doesn't seem to fit in with the rest of the numbers here.  Standouts include the rocker Slip Kid, the memorable Blue, Red, and Grey, and the albums capper How Many Friends. <br />  When I critically think about this work, I keep thinking of the amazing range displayed here.  Not only to write these disjointed songs about the depths of sleaze that wealth, fortune, and stardom bring, but for these guys to realize this while they were still very young and in the midst of a fantastic career (they are all 2 decades away from any venerable mid-life crisis).  Its as if, Peter and Roger took a step back while taking a step foward.  They must have known this work would not be a large commercial hit, so why not ride this theme out and be satisfied at having expressed the pain and angst at being adored by so many, not because of who you are, but who you represent being.  It's bittersweet, but I love it, love its bad attitude, and recommend it to all, except those of you on prozac, paxil, xanax, or any other anti-depressant as it may be too much for you right now. <br />  -Goodbye all you Punks, stay young and stay high-

He has basically constructed a novel out of different themed chapters, all focusing on some odd perspective about a different time in his life.  My favorite was when he talked about his sister Amy, that chapter made me giggle to myself for the rest of the day. <br />I found that this book was the *perfect* book to take to the gym and read during my cardio workout.  1) It has no complex, deeply woven plot that you have to concentrate intently on, so you can cruise along reading while running in place 2) It is written well enough to hold your attention and 3) It is funny enough to make you concentrate on that instead of running in place.  <br />If that is a good analogy for how you like your books, then here ya go.

Gone are the bombastic drums and guitars riff and added are soulful arrangements that not only showcases Degraw unique voice, but his passionate lyrics as well. <br /> On songs such as ~Nice To Meet You Anyway~ and ~Belief~ Degraw takes what was once beautiful rock tracks to endearing acoustic standouts. His voice weaves hauntingly between the lyrics, allowing the lyrics to take the front seat and shine. <br /> Other notables are his new versions of ~More Than Anyone~ and his recent single ~I Don't Want To Be Anyone~; in these tracks Gavin vocals are lamented over each melody in an effortless way.  <br /> But the standout track has to be the newly recorded version of Sam Cooke's swan song, ~Change Is Gonna Come~. The album, in a way, arcs itself to this song that should easily set Degraw apart from his Jason Mraz and John Mayer counterparts. Degraw's voice is the star in this song that captures the yearning and heartache Cooke originally conveyed in his version. It is truly a respectful cover.  <br /> Degraw may not be a mainstream artist as of yet, but hopefully with this newly released version of his already classic debut he will be more than just another voice on the radio, but a staple in the music world. <br />

B0000WN0ZK|3.0|You'll hate it if you like Hollywood movies. You'll love it if you recognize it as the human condition expressed using visuals only--a revolutionary idea when Antonioni first tried it. He selected every object in every scene for its symbolic meaning, even though the movie's theme is that meaning is impossible to know. But his hero tries to create meaning anyway, since he lives in an age where Existentialism, Marshall McCluhan, and the beginning of mass electronic media are eroding meaning. It's \\"art for the artist's sake\\"--fascinating if you're on the artist's wavelength, boring if you're not; but important for its historic significance to film-making.

There are lots of references to Dickens, 19th century schools of thought and people and places of the times.<br /><br />You can read the real book young-- I read it in 6th grade, and it's still one of my faves.But your child will not get it until they are much older, not matter how gifted they are!!!!!!!!!!!!<br /><br />An adaptation is not the answer. It's like feeding your child a pint of spaghetti sauce that has been drowned in a quart of water--the original is there, but the flavor is gone. And so it the nutrition!!!<br /><br />There are plenty of books your child will enjoy and RELATE to. Wait to read the real thing. Or if you really insist on exposing them to the story before they can read it, let them see one of the film versions first--they were all pretty good.

From haunting acoustic guitar bits to driving hard rock (sometimes within the same song!), it sucks you in like nothing you've ever heard before. There are 9 or 10 different singers on this cd (including Arjen himself), and they all add their own elements without overpowering it. The songs have a lot of variety to them, but fit together so perfectly, even when you're going from a screaming guitar solo (the end of Amazing Flight in Space) to an acoustic number (Time Beyond Time). The storyline is kind of cheesy, reminiscent of the old pulp sci-fi novels, but is very interesting, and ties everything together.  <br />  <br /> One of the coolest cd's I've ever heard, but definitely made for people who like different styles and types of music. If you're into the whole zero-creativity-and-originality mainstream music scene, don't bother, you'll just find it strange and confusing. But if you're looking for something different, pick this up and you will not be disapointed! <br />  <br />Favorite song: ALL OF THEM!  I had some favorites when I first started listening to this, but the more I listened, the more I got into the whole album. So I can't really pick a particular song, they're all so good!

Using the ever popular 'passion over pitch' method of raw, emotional recordings, Gavin re-recorded all the songs 100% live in a studio with an acoustic band all in one take, completely stripped of all the engineering & over producing that record lables use to get more radio friendly sounding songs.<br /><br /> Not since Lauryn Hill's Unplugged have I heard an album so real, so focused & so incredibly inspiring. While his debut was an astonishing release, STRIPPED easily surpasses it because this is the way I believe Gavin initially intended the listener to hear his work. Who could have imagined tracks such as &quot;Follow Through&quot;, &quot;Belief&quot;, &quot;Just Friends&quot;, &quot;Over-rated&quot; & &quot;I Don't Want to Be&quot; could sound any better than their original recordings. Now its time to let that secret out. This music is purely timeless, an influential masterpiece that only comes along every so often. For one to pass on this release could even be a sin. 0201633612|5.0|There is not a day does by that some pattern in this book is used in the daily work at my software firm. These idioms have come to dominate software development: they are both useful in themselves, and they increasingly form a common language for software designers that is abstracted from details such as implementation language or problem domain. <br /> <br />In order to truly use this book, the developer really needs to incorporate an intuitive knowledge of these patterns, how to implement them, and their relative costs and benefits, into his set of skills. <br /> <br />Some of the simpler patterns are those that occurred to me only after doing things badly in OO designs for years (My first OO experience was in C++ over 10 years ago). Others would not have occurred to me and have saved me heartache in the problems I currently face. <br /> <br />One thing that would be nice would be an update that included Java examples and new patterns. Still, this book is indispensable. If you're a software developer and you don't have it, buy it and read it.

B00005JLD4|5.0|I will forever be grateful to Roger Ebert and Richard Roeper for having reviewed their film on their TV show.  Indeed, that's how I heard of it and immediately placed it on my list of must-see films. <br /> <br />It's a heart rending film, at least to human beings with compassion.  I had heard from Australian friends that, historically, Australia had treated Aborigines as badly as the United States had treated American Indians, but I knew none of the specifics. <br /> <br />Rabbit-Proof Fence, based on the book Follow the Rabbit-Proof Fence by Doris Pilkington Garimara, gives its audience an insight into a blatantly racist policy in place in Australia from the early 1930's through the beginning of the 1970's.  Here, we learn of three \\"half-caste\\" Aboriginal girls, sisters Molly and Daisy and their first cousin Grace, whose biological fathers are white and whose mothers are Aborigines.  Empowered by the Aborigines Regulation of 1931, the government systematically arrested children of mixed race and removed them from their parents, transporting them huge distances to boarding schools that differed little from concentration camps.  There, the children were forced to speak English only and educated to become domestic servants to be placed with white people.  The program's purpose was to prevent them from having children with aboriginal spouses.  Children who ran away from the camps were hunted down, brought back, put in solitary confinement and beaten severely. <br /> <br />In the instant story, the three children, miserable in their new surroundings at 14, 12 and 8 years old, escape despite the possible consequences and walk home, a distance of 1,500 miles.  Australia had constructed a system of rabbit-proof fences, designed to keep the burgeoning rabbit population (a species introduced from Europe with no natural enemies in Australia) from further invading farmlands.  The girls know that the rabbit-proof fence goes through their home settlement and stretches for thousands of miles, so they follow it. <br /> <br />The film gives us a look at their journey and as they progress over nine weeks. <br /> <br />Australian filmmaker Philip Noyce has done an outstanding job.  This story requires no complicated treatment and none is given.  It all looks very real and Noyce did an outstanding job locating the three Aborigine girls who play Molly, Grace and Daisy.  By the way, it's Molly's daughter who wrote the book Follow the Rabbit Proof Fence based on her mother's own story. <br /> <br />We Americans should be able to appreciate this film given our own history with regard to our aboriginal people, the American Indians.  We need to know this story because we need to take a stand that such things should never again be allowed to happen. <br /> <br />

0743442539|5.0|THE SPY WHO CAME IN FROM THE COLD is the quintessential cold war espionage novel.  For four decades, this early LeCarre tale has served as the benchmark for 'spy thriller' writing.  Reading it fresh in 2004, it's easy to see why. <br /> <br />Though THE SPY WHO CAME IN FROM THE COLD was only LeCarre's third novel, his strengths as a storyteller are fully evident here.  The opening chapter alone serves as a narrative tour-de-force, swiftly and adroitly introducing the reader to the central characters, their impossible situation, and the hopeless, duplicitous world they inhabit.  It is beautfully mirrored by the final chapter, in which the consequences of protagonist Alec Leamas' weakness becomes excruciatingly, tragically clear.   <br /> <br />In terms of both style and structure, this early work seems to take its cues from Grahame Greene's '50s novels -- particularly THE QUIET AMERICAN.  As in Greene, LeCarre's descriptions here are spare and succinct, with characters and situations quickly sketched in razor-sharp detail.  Like Greene, this writer shows that sacrifice of innocents at the hands of arrogant ideologues has become mundane.  He reveals the tragic complicity of all-too-human agents like Alec Leamas.  Yet LeCarre does not share Greene's belief in personal redemption:  His characters take it for granted that they live in an amoral labyrinth in which treachery and triple-cross are simply routine. <br /> <br />Economy and intelligence are hallmarks of this work.  Dialogue is terse, sharp; plot complications are introduced with a minimum of fuss.  LeCarre sketches his players deftly, in medias res, as they run the gauntlet.   Consequently, this 224-page novel can be read in two sittings, yet its characters and situations seem fully realized -- and its tragic conclusion hits with tremendous impact. <br /> <br />THE SPY WHO CAME IN FROM THE COLD is an early work, by a writer still looking to more experienced hands for models.  It would be almost a decade beforeLeCarre truly came into his own, with TINKER TAILOR SOLDIER SPY.  Still, it's clear that this novel is more than just a superlatively crafted  'spy thriller', more than just a classic of the genre.  Forty years after its first publication, LeCarre's tragic tale has lost none of its power:  THE SPY WHO CAME IN FROM THE COLD remains an extraordinary masterwork, by a supremely gifted and intelligent writer.

But to introduce someone to Elvis you simply couldn't put together a better example. Sit back, listen

B000002KB8|4.0|Black Sabbath began when four schoolmates from Birmingham, England, Ozzy Osbourne, Tony Iommi, Geezer Butler, and Bill Ward quit their bands (Ozzy and Geezer were in Rare Breed, Tony and Bill were in Mythology) and joined forces to become the Polka Tulk Blues Band in 1968 which was eventually shortened to &quot;Polka Tulk&quot; Ernest Chataway on Rhythm Guitar and Alan Clark on Saxophone. Chataway eventually quit the band and Jimmy Phillips came in on Slide Guitar. The band then dropped both Phillips and Clark and changed their name to &quot;Earth&quot;. Apparently, there was another band called Earth in the area, which led to a club booking Ozzy and the gang expecting a completely different kind of music. To avoid confusion, the band renamed themselves &quot;Black Sabbath&quot; after a movie playing across the street from where the band rehearsed (Butler thought it sounded dark and gloomy). On the day that Iommi was to quit his job to fully devote his time to Sabbath, his fingertips were chopped off in an accident at his workplace. Iommi was inspired by the great jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt, whose third and fourth fingers were fused from birth and useless. Iommi experimented with many materials until he found that putting plastic &quot;fingertips&quot; on his fingers would allow him to play again. However, he would have to give the strings more slack, so he tuned them down a step and a half, which created Sabbath's muddy sound and gave birth to Heavy Metal itself. <br /> On February Thirteenth, 1970, Black Sabbath released this album in United Kingdom on the Vertigo label, and released it on June First, 1970 in United States on the Warner label. This album eventually sold Platinum in United States, making it the third-top-selling album in Black Sabbath history. <br /> This was the band's first album and was outsold by their second album, &quot;&quot;Paranoid&quot;&quot;. This album is one of the greatest guitar albums of all time. This album included the lineupof: <br /> (Thanks to Black Sabbath Online): <br /> * Tony Iommi - Lead Guitar & Keyboards <br /> * Geezer Butler - Bass <br /> * Ozzy Osbourne - Vocals * <br /> * Bill Ward - Drums <br /> * Roger Bain - Producer (for Tony Hall Enterprises) <br /> * Tom Allom & Barry Sheffield - Engineers  <br />  <br /> * - Spelled Ossie Osbourne on the original version of the album. <br />  <br /> All songs are Iommi/Osborne/Butler/Ward, except for &quot;Warning&quot;, which is by Ansley Dunbar. <br />  <br /> &quot;Black Sabbath&quot; (6:20) (5/5): Dark, gloomy, and slow. The second-best song on this album. <br />  <br /> &quot;The Wizard&quot; (4:23) (4/5): Bluesy, heavy rocker with Ozzy on harmonica. Incredible drumming from Bill Ward. <br />  <br /> &quot;Behind The Wall Of Sleep/Wasp&quot; and &quot;N.I.B./Basically&quot; (9:44) (5/5): On this CD, these two songs are combined. In &quot;Wasp&quot;, Iommi just plays the guitar, and well. &quot;Behind The Wall Of Sleep&quot; is a somewhat melodic, heavy, echoy rocker. &quot;Basically&quot; is an awesome bass solo. &quot;N.I.B.&quot; is pure genius, and &quot;N.I.B./Basically&quot; together make the greatest bass performance by Geezer Butler ever and the fourth-greatest on the album. <br />  <br /> &quot;Wicked World&quot; (4:46) (5/5): &quot;Wicked World&quot; is Black Sabbath's greatest song, no doubt. Completely awesome. A hard-rocking song. &quot;Wicked World&quot; is also the best song on this album. <br />  <br /> &quot;Sleeping Village/A Bit Of Finger&quot; and &quot;Warning&quot; (14:15) (5/5): On this CD, these two songs are combined. &quot;Sleeping Village/A Bit Of Finger&quot; is a good, hard rocker. &quot;Warning&quot; is excellent. Included is Tony Iommi's greatest guitar solo.
B000002AP1|5.0|If The Stooges had never recorded anything else, they would still be worthy of legendary status based on this.  If you have never heard this album, no opinion of music you hold could ever possibly matter in the great scheme of things.
B0001Z52RU|5.0|Ashton Kutcher's first dramatic/dark movie is an underrated (Amazon-vote wise, not box office) tale of a guy with memory-changing powers. Evan, Ashton's character, has had multiple blackouts during his childhood, usually when a stressful or highly traumatic event occurs. Later in his life, he reviews journals he kept of those days and finds himself able to relive those memories, and ultimately change them. <br />  <br /> The reason I am giving this movie 5 stars is because it is so uniquely original. It has the gumption to portray an ugly childhood (something very few movies have the courage to do), and the ending(s) of both the theatrical and director's cut are so unique and appropriate that they truly reflect Evan's character and the lessons he learned. The ending is gutsy and flawless, as opposed to one that pandered to the quick atavistic wants of a sappy, happy ending needing crowd. May I say that the above DVD also includes the sappy version for those home video owners who feel that they cannot sleep without knowing &quot;everything turned out okay.&quot; <br />  <br /> This movie has the most amazing casting I've ever seen in a film. Not only did the double directors find a surprisingly perfect adult cast (with Amy Smart able to play four different Kayleigh's), they found two groups of 4 kids each that resembled the adult character in different stages of childhood. You might as well be fooled into believing this movie was shot over 15 years, as these characters appear to be, in essence, that character when he was 22, 13, 8, etc. These kids are absolutely (add italics and bold type) indistinguishable from the character when he/she was older. <br />  <br /> The plot, as some reviewers have suggested, has some minor holes but I believe they can be patched fairly quickly. One reviewer comments that Evan keeps his journals even after he changes his past so often. Well, you can't change human nature, and while there remain traumatizing events in Evan's life, he will be destined to keep journal entries. Additionally, Evan does not always have these journals with him. Later in the movie, when he finds himself at the Sunnyvale Institution, he is journal-less, as his father was, who it is deeply hinted had the same power. The plot is absolutely excellent, and flawless. It is especially intriguing to see where Evan ends up after changing one slight detail in his past. Just as a satellite dish can be moved one sixteenth of an inch and miss its target satellite by 3000 miles, a slight detail change in your childhood could very well have put you on a much different path in your adulthood. This is in essence the chaos theory of the butterfly effect. Absolutely excellent concepts. <br />  <br /> This movie was dark, and may not appeal to some viewers. It contains very violent scenes. In particular, a child sets fire to a dog, and a little girl is hit in the side of the head with a 2x4. Also there are deep undertones of father-daughter molestation. Simply my mentioning these scenes may turn some potential viewers off of this movie, but these scenes are absolutely essential to understand the character development within the story, and to show the viewer that all childhoods are not pleasant, merry, and held in good memory. <br />  <br /> In conclusion, this is an excellent film. It was a movie the directors had planned and written and rewritten and storyboarded over 7 years. The DVD, with the Infinifilm option, is excellent, as you can match up storyboards to the scenes. It subtely reminds me of &quot;Pop Up Video&quot;, now long gone from VH1. Furthermore, the DVD includes a help menu on absolutely everything, a pleasant change that even includes instructions on how to adjust your television settings to color bars. Five Stars, both hands numb from holding my thumbs up.

I do not see Robert Jordan's failings creeping into Martin's writing. Holding to the theme of a quasi-history novel, Martin begins to stir things up a little bit more with some magic-related things. You may dislike certain characters, but by the end of this book, you will better understand them and their desires.     Simply amazing, really. This is epic fantasy at its best . . . no, this is adult fantasy at its best. The deepest sorrows, but the depth of humanity in the characters is unrivaled.

B00008CLOA|5.0|Dark Side of the Moon has undoubtedly been one of the most popular albums for decades, and with good reasons. The lyrics are very well written alongside the instrumental compositions. The opening track Speak To Me has signature bits from the songs that follow, giving you a look at the varying aspects the album has to offer. <br />  <br /> Breathe is a slow-going song that pretty much sets the tone for Dark Side of the Moon. The instrumental On The Run features quick-paced synthesizer sounds which represent the title well. Time brings back the lyrics expressing the discontent with the seemingly unyielding speed in which our lives seem to go. The Great Gig In The Sky is another instrumental that this time features the wailing voice of Clare Torry as an instrument - not necessarily singing words. Money is a song stressing society's common bond of greed and its ill effects.  <br />  <br /> Us and Them is my personal favorite of the album - there doesn't really seem to be a core message in this song, but it invokes an intense sense of emotion throughout both the lyrics and music. Any Colour You Like is a fairly funky instrumental followed up by the relatively well-known Brain Damage, a song about madness. Eclipse finalizes a very unique album that I think deserves a chance from listeners of all genres. This was my first and favorite Pink Floyd album and I highly recommend Dark Side of the Moon to anyone who is willing to give it a try.
